DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Flammable mixture not subject to RMP as the entire mixture meets NFPA-3 criteria

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description
POET Biorefining - Alexandria, LLC. is located approximately two miles northeast of Alexandria, Indiana, in Madison County.  POET Biorefining-Alexandria's main product is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel.  The facility also produces vegetable (corn) oil, purified alcohol and dried distillers grain.  Ethanol production at the facility was initiated in April, 2008.   POET Biorefining-Alexandria produces ethanol using the dry mill method. Corn meal is mixed with water and a digestive enzyme to produce starch resulting in mash.  Yeast is added to the mash to ferment the sugars to ethanol.  The fermented mash (beer) contains about 20% alcohol and is distilled, then passed through a dehydration system to produce 200-proof anhydrous ethanol. After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two 2,000,000 gallon storage tanks.  During load-out from these tanks, a denaturant (natural gas condensate, NGC) is added as per federal and state requirements to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption.  The NGC denaturant is stored in Tank No 802.  Tank 802 has a capacity of 257,000 gallons (approximately 1,618,000 pounds).  NGC is blended with the ethanol during load-out and denatured ethanol is shipped from the facility in tank trucks and rail cars.

Chemicals Regulated Under EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Program
The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical which exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation. The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of the NGC denaturant storage tank and the associated transfer/blending equipment and piping. The denaturant is added to the ethanol to a concentration of 2% to 3%. Line 1.17(c)of this submission is the total quantity of this tank.  As recommended by U.S. EPA's RMP Information Office on June 10,  2013, Line 4.4 of the Worst Case Scenario submission is taken as QR (Eq. D-1; Risk Management Program Guidance for Off Site Consequence Analysis, EPA 5

50-B-99-009, March, 2009.), i.e., pounds released per minute and multiplied times ten minutes to reflect the quantity that is estimated to evaporate and participate in an un-contained vapor cloud explosion.  Details of the calculation methodology are in Appendix D of the POET Biorefining-Alexandria Desktop Risk Management Plan.     

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
POET Biorefining-Alexandria is committed to the protection of it employees, the surrounding community and the environment from industrial materials used in the ethanol fuel production process. The company has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) as per 29 CFR 1910.38(a).  In the event of a chemical  emergency, POET Biorefining-Alexandria's Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of materials. There is no facility emergency response team. Employees within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such response does not pose a danger to their health or safety. In the event of a larger release, it is the policy of POET Biorefining-Alexandria to notify the Alexandria Fire Department, evacuate all employees at the facility, and provide technical and logistics support to the Fire Department Incident Commander.

Accidental Release Prevention Program, and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
POET Biorefining-Alexandria is committed to protection of the environment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, passive mitigation, employee training and response preparation.  Computer based maintenance software (Maximo) is utilized to implement automatic scheduling and work order generation for covered process  preventative maintenance inspections and tests.  The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The

re is a multi-camera video surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer based alarm system. The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage tanks and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill monitors). The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible alarms. Critical aspects of process control can be performed remotely.  The covered process  storage tanks have secondary containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.

Five-Year Accident History
The facility has an excellent record with regard to minimizing recordable and reportable accidents. There have been no accidents since startup of the facility which require inclusion in the five-year accident history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
There are no current design projects or equipment procurements planned in this category at the time of this submission; however, POET Biorefining-Alexandria's management and operations team is committed to an on-going system of production process review, evaluation of improvements in available technology (including safety features), analysis of previous plant incidents (including near misses), SPOT (Safety Procedure Observation Tool) checks, and Prevention Program compliance audits, to identify opportunities to improve plant safety.
